blocks.description: The derivative of the function with respect to p.

blocks.text:
Integrating the second expression gives: 

\[ \int \left(\frac{1}{3} (\rho - \rho_{0} + 83)\right) dp = \frac{1}{3}(\rho p - \rho_{0} p + 83p) + C. \]

Notice that although a function has been differentiated and the derivative produced, the integral retains exactly the constant term, the constant term being represented only by C, where C can have any value. Further mention will be made to this point on p. 137.

Example 6.1 — Find the value of \(\rho_p\). 
To express \(\rho_p\) in terms of \(C\): 

\[\rho_p = C \frac{1}{3} \left(\frac{1}{2} \frac{(1)}{p^{(1-3)}} + 1 + \frac{1}{K} \right)\] 
 
(K being an auxiliary constant)

This result can be written in a slightly different form, if C were written as \(\rho_p\): then—

blocks.description: An alternative expression for \(\rho_p\) using C.

blocks.text:
Example 7 — Find \(\rho_p\) when \(p = C\). 
In this case—

blocks.description: Expression evaluated for the specific case where \(p = C\).

blocks.text:
Example 8 — Find the value of \(C\). 

\[ C = 17 \log \frac{\rho_p}{\rho} \] 
Notice that C is a constant multiplier throughout; it multiplies the I.V. and therefore appears as a divisor after integration; also the power of e remains exactly the same.
